document.heading: Fiscal Year 2023 Revised Local Budget Adjustment Emergency Act of 2023
To adjust, on an emergency basis, certain allocations in the Fiscal Year 2023 Local Budget Act of 2022 to maintain a balanced budget for the fiscal year ending September 30, 2023.
document.text: BE IT ENACTED BY THE COUNCIL OF THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA, That this act may be cited as the "Fiscal Year 2023 Revised Local Budget Adjustment Emergency Act of 2023".

section.text: The appropriations set forth in the Fiscal Year 2023 Local Budget Act of 2022, effective September 9, 2022 (D.C. Law 24-166; 69 DCR 8870), are increased by $25,053,575 (including ($20,128,699) rescinded from local funds, ($375,000) rescinded from dedicated taxes, ($20,690,000) rescinded from federal grant funds, ($10,444,625) rescinded from other funds, and $76,691,899 added to federal payment funds for COVID relief), to be allocated as follows:

para.text: The appropriation for Governmental Direction and Support is decreased by ($10,144,614) (including ($10,204,614) rescinded from local funds and $60,000 added to other funds), to be allocated as follows:
Advisory Neighborhood Commissions: ($206,492) is rescinded from local funds;
Board of Elections: ($150,000) is rescinded from local funds;
Board of Ethics and Government Accountability: $60,000 is added to other funds;
Contract Appeals Board: ($23,455) is rescinded from local funds;
Department of General Services: ($4,904,579) is rescinded from local funds;
Department of Human Resources: ($15,000) is rescinded from local funds;
Office of Contracting and Procurement: ($200,000) is rescinded from local funds;
Office of Disability Rights: ($95,000) is rescinded from local funds;
Office of Labor Relations and Collective Bargaining: ($296,884) is rescinded from local funds;
Office of the Chief Financial Officer: ($2,393,204) is rescinded from local funds;
Office of the District of Columbia Auditor: ($1,000,000) is rescinded from local funds;
Office of the Inspector General: ($500,000) is rescinded from local funds;
Office of the Secretary of State: ($20,000) is rescinded from local funds; and
Tax Revision Commission: ($400,000) is rescinded from local funds.

The appropriation for Economic Development and Regulation is decreased by ($42,481,305) (including ($27,368,206) rescinded from local funds, ($11,363,099) rescinded from other funds, and ($3,750,000) rescinded from federal payment funds for COVID relief), to be allocated as follows:
Department of Housing and Community Development: ($6,480,023) is rescinded from local funds;
Department of Small and Local Business Development: ($474,200) is rescinded from local funds;
Housing Authority Subsidy: ($17,769,483) is rescinded from local funds;
Office of Planning: ($350,000) is rescinded from local funds;

Office of the Deputy Mayor for Planning and Economic Development: ($17,273,199) is rescinded (including ($2,160,100) rescinded from local funds, ($11,363,099) rescinded from other funds, and ($3,750,000) rescinded from federal payment funds for COVID relief);
Office of the Tenant Advocate: ($110,000) is rescinded from local funds; and
Real Property Tax Appeals Commission: ($24,400) is rescinded from local funds.

The appropriation for Public Safety and Justice is decreased by ($12,638,222) (including ($4,027,066) rescinded from local funds, $858,474 added to other funds, and ($9,469,630) rescinded from federal payment funds for COVID relief), to be allocated as follows:
Criminal Justice Coordinating Council: ($300,000) is rescinded from local funds;
Department of Corrections: ($2,000,000) is rescinded from local funds;
Department of Youth Rehabilitation Services: $497,117 is added (including ($125,000) rescinded from local funds and $622,117 added to other funds);
District of Columbia National Guard: ($268,385) is rescinded from local funds;
Metropolitan Police Department: ($359,000) is rescinded from federal payment funds for COVID relief;
Office of Administrative Hearings: ($636,484) is rescinded from local funds;
Office of Human Rights: ($1,061,650) is rescinded from local funds;
Office of Neighborhood Safety and Engagement: ($2,162,998) is rescinded (including ($1,644,564) rescinded from local funds and ($518,434) rescinded from federal payment funds for COVID relief);
Office of the Chief Medical Examiner: ($130,000) is rescinded from local funds;
Office of the Deputy Mayor for Public Safety and Justice: ($195,921) is rescinded from local funds;
Office of Unified Communications: ($2,291,232) is rescinded (including ($2,527,589) rescinded from local funds and $236,357 added to other funds);
Office of Victim Services and Justice Grants: ($3,704,669) is rescinded (including $4,887,527 added to local funds and ($8,592,196) rescinded from federal payment funds for COVID relief); and
Office on Returning Citizens Affairs: ($25,000) is rescinded from local funds.

The appropriation for Public Education System is decreased by ($69,799,662) (including ($30,908,495) rescinded from local funds, ($375,000) rescinded from dedicated taxes, ($20,690,000) rescinded from federal grant funds, and ($17,826,168) rescinded from federal payment funds for COVID relief), to be allocated as follows:
Department of Employment Services: ($3,515,803) is rescinded (including $10,872,033 added to local funds and ($14,387,836) rescinded from federal payment funds for COVID relief);
Department of Parks and Recreation: ($320,000) is rescinded from local funds;
District of Columbia Public Charter Schools: ($13,000,000) is rescinded from local funds;
District of Columbia Public Schools: ($15,000,000) is rescinded from local funds;
Non-Public Tuition: ($4,650,000) is rescinded from local funds;
Office of the Deputy Mayor for Education: ($3,973,331) is rescinded (including ($535,000) rescinded from local funds and ($3,438,331) rescinded from federal payment funds for COVID relief);

Office of the State Superintendent of Education: ($26,785,528) is rescinded (including ($5,720,528) rescinded from local funds, ($375,000) rescinded from dedicated taxes, and ($20,690,000) rescinded from federal grant funds);
Special Education Transportation: ($2,100,000) is rescinded from local funds;
State Board of Education: $45,000 is added to local funds; and
Unemployment Compensation Fund: ($500,000) is rescinded from local funds.

The appropriation for Human Support Services is decreased by ($37,012,201) (including ($147,104,500) rescinded from local funds and $110,092,299 added to federal payment funds for COVID relief), to be allocated as follows:
Child and Family Services Agency: ($398,620) is rescinded from local funds;

Department of Behavioral Health: ($3,931,104) is rescinded (including ($2,432,410) rescinded from local funds and ($1,498,694) rescinded from federal payment funds for COVID relief); provided, that all funds deposited, without regard to fiscal year, into the Opioid Abatement Fund are authorized for expenditure and shall remain available for expenditure until September 30, 2023;
Department on Disability Services: ($6,262,480) is rescinded from local funds;
Department of Health: ($1,000,000) is rescinded from local funds;
Department of Health Care Finance: ($22,730,000) is rescinded from local funds;
Department of Human Services: ($2,518,659) is rescinded (including ($114,109,651) rescinded from local funds and $111,590,993 added to federal payment funds for COVID relief); and
Office of the Deputy Mayor for Health and Human Services: ($171,338) is rescinded from local funds.

The appropriation for Operations and Infrastructure is decreased by ($15,861,534) (including ($14,175,287) rescinded from local funds and ($1,686,247) rescinded from federal payment funds for COVID relief), to be allocated as follows:
Department of Buildings: ($4,490,833) is rescinded from local funds;
Department of Energy and Environment: ($1,686,247) is rescinded from federal payment funds for COVID relief;
Department of Licensing and Consumer Protection: ($1,038,750) is rescinded from local funds;
Department of Motor Vehicles: ($350,000) is rescinded from local funds;
Department of Public Works: ($3,736,009) is rescinded from local funds;
Department of Transportation: ($715,495) is rescinded from local funds;
Office of the People's Counsel: ($244,200) is rescinded from local funds; and
Washington Metropolitan Area Transit Authority: ($3,600,000) is rescinded from local funds.

The appropriation for Financing and Other is increased by $212,991,113 (including $213,659,469 added to local funds and ($668,356) rescinded from federal payment funds for COVID relief), to be allocated as follows:
Convention Center Transfer: ($23,000,000) is rescinded from local funds;
Non-Departmental Account: $14,932,644 is added (including $15,601,000 added to local funds and ($668,356) rescinded from federal payment funds for COVID relief);
Repayment of Contingency Reserve Fund: $18,976,779 is added to local funds;
Repayment of Loans and Interest: ($38,000,000) is rescinded from local funds;
Settlements and Judgments: ($6,975,241) is rescinded from local funds; and

Workforce Investments Account: $247,056,931 is added to local funds; provided, that all funds deposited, without regard to fiscal year, into the Workforce Investments Account are authorized for expenditure and shall remain available for expenditure until September 30, 2023.

section.codify:annotation: For an emergency (90-day) adjustment, on an emergency basis, of certain allocations in the Fiscal Year 2023 Local Budget Act of 2022 to maintain a balanced budget for the fiscal year ending September 30, 2023, see the Fiscal Year 2023 Revised Local Budget Adjustment Emergency Act of 2023, D.C. Act 25-134, June 27, 2023, 70 DCR 9048.

For an emergency (90-day) adjustment, on an emergency basis, of certain allocations in the Fiscal Year 2023 Local Budget Act of 2022 to maintain a balanced budget for the fiscal year ending September 30, 2023, see the Fiscal Year 2023 Revised Local Budget Adjustment Emergency Act of 2023, D.C. Act 25-134, June 27, 2023, 70 DCR 9048.

section.heading: Capital project rescissions and increases.
section.text: In Fiscal Year 2023, the capital project appropriations for Fiscal Year 2023 shall be increased or decreased as set forth in the following tabular array:

tr.th: DDOT - CIRCULATOR BUS DEPOT - CLAY BRICK
POR & TEST FIT OF MPD PATROL DISTRICTS
UPGRADE FIRE ALARM AND SPRINKLER SYSTEM

para.text: Notwithstanding any provision of law limiting the use of funds in the accounts listed in the following chart, the Chief Financial Officer shall transfer in Fiscal Year 2023 the following amounts from certified funds and other revenue in the identified accounts to the unassigned fund balance of the General Fund of the District of Columbia:

tr.td: 6031-DC CIRCULATOR BUS SYSTEM - NPS MALL ROUTE

para.text: Notwithstanding any provision of law limiting the use of funds in the accounts listed in D.C. Official Code ยง 47-392.02(j-5)(1) and (2), the amounts deposited and committed to those accounts pursuant to D.C. Official Code ยง 47-392.02(j-5) in Fiscal Year 2023, based on the Annual Comprehensive Financial Report for Fiscal Year 2022, shall, after such deposits and commitments have been made, be transferred by the Chief Financial Officer before September 30, 2023, to the unassigned balance of the General Fund of the District of Columbia.

Notwithstanding any provision of law, in Fiscal Year 2023, the Chief Financial Officer shall deposit $171,775 of unassigned fund balance into the Emergency and Non-Emergency Number Telephone Calling Systems Fund established pursuant to section 603 of the Emergency and Non-Emergency Telephone Calling Systems Fund Act of 2000, effective October 19, 2000 (D.C. Law 13-172; D.C. Official Code ยง 34-1802).
The amounts identified in subsections (a), (b), and (c) of this section shall be made available as set forth in the approved Fiscal Year 2024 Budget and Financial Plan.

section.heading: Remaining Fiscal Year 2023 unexpended revenue of $397,077,739 shall be carried over into Fiscal Year 2024 as fund balance and shall be available as set forth in the approved Fiscal Year 2024 Budget and Financial Plan.

para.text: For School Year 2023-2024, the Office of the State Superintendent of Education ("OSSE") shall make direct payments in a total amount of $73,572,698 from the Workforce Investments Account to public charter LEAs for the purpose of:

Increasing compensation retroactively at a rate of 7.6% over a public charter LEA's School Year 2022-2023 pay scale for teachers whom a public charter LEA employed as of October 5, 2022, and who remain employed by the LEA as of September 1, 2023;
Increasing compensation prospectively at a rate of 12.5% over a public charter LEA's School Year 2019-2020 pay scale for teachers whom an LEA employs as of September 1, 2023; and
If funds remain after making payments to increase teacher compensation pursuant to paragraphs (1) and (2) of this subsection, increasing compensation for school-based educators and support staff.
OSSE may issue payments authorized pursuant to subsection (a) of this section beginning July 1, 2023.
To be eligible for a direct payment under subsection (a) of this section, a public charter LEA shall submit to OSSE:
The public charter LEA's School Year 2019-2020 pay scale by steps and grades, if applicable, or the minimum, average, and maximum salaries for teachers in School Year 2019-2020.
The total amount the public charter LEA spent on teacher salaries in School Year 2022-2023;

The public charter LEA's School Year 2023-2024 teacher pay scale by steps and grades and number of teachers in each step and grade or, if applicable, the LEA's School Year 2023-2024 minimum, average, and maximum salaries for teachers and number of teachers, which shall demonstrate a 12.5% increase between School Year 2019-2020 and School Year 2023-2024 ranges, and documentation that it has publicly posted the pay scale;

If a public charter LEA does not have a teacher pay scale, a signed assurance from the public charter LEA's Chief Executive Officer or Head of School that it will develop and publicly post a teacher pay scale by steps and grades by May 1, 2024, to be implemented in School Year 2024-2025; and
A signed assurance from the public charter LEA's Chief Executive Officer or Head of School that:
The School Year 2023-2024 teacher pay scale will be at least 12.5% higher than its School Year 2019-2020 pay scale; and

The public charter LEA will provide the retroactive 7.6% salary increase required pursuant to subsection (a)(1) of this section to all employees who were employed as a teacher as of October 5, 2022, and who remain employed by the public charter LEA, as a teacher or otherwise, as of September 1, 2023;

If, by June 30, 2024, OSSE determines that a public charter LEA that received payments authorized by this section has failed to comply with the provisions of this section or failed to use the money in accordance with the purposes authorized in subsection (a) of this section, the public charter LEA shall return, in a manner specified by OSSE, any portion of the payments determined by OSSE to be in violation of the requirements of this section, regardless of whether the public charter LEA disbursed the funding; except, that a public charter LEA may not require teachers to return any compensation they received from payments made under this section.
OSSE shall provide the public charter LEA with an opportunity to cure the violation prior to requiring repayment.
For the purposes of this section, the term:
"Public charter LEA" means an individual or a group of public charter schools operating under a single charter.

"Teacher" means a school-based employee who provides instruction in a core or non-core academic subject, and includes general or special education teachers instructing students in the core subject areas of English language arts, math, science, and social studies, as well as non-core subjects such as arts, foreign language, and physical education, but excludes student support professionals such as speech therapists or social workers, counselors, librarians, coaches, principals, special education coordinators, program coordinators, deans, office staff, custodians, or any other non-instructional personnel.

section.text: Section 47-368.07(b)(2) of the District of Columbia Official Code is amended by striking the phrase "Payments to public charter schools authorized by section 204 of the Fiscal Year 2018 Budget Support Clarification Act of 2018, passed on 2nd reading on April 10, 2018 (Enrolled version of Bill 22-466)" and inserting the phrase "Payments to public charter schools authorized to be paid from the Account by other District law" in its place.

para.text: Section 301 of the Opioid Litigation Proceeds Amendment Act of 2022, effective March 10, 2023 (D.C. Law 24-315; 70 DCR 838), is repealed.
Section 4 of the William Dorsey Swann Street Designation Act of 2023, enacted on May 24, 2023 (D.C. Act 25-103; 70 DCR 7914), is repealed.
Section 47-392.02(j-1)(2) of the District of Columbia Official Code is amended as follows:
Subparagraph (B) is amended by striking the phrase "; and" and inserting a semicolon in its place.
Subparagraph (C) is amended by striking the period at the end and inserting the phrase "; and" in its place.
A new subparagraph (D) is added to read as follows:
Funding for locally appropriated expenditures in Fiscal Year 2023.

section.text: Paragraph (5) under the heading Governmental Direction and Support in section 2 of the Fiscal Year 2023 Local Budget Act of 2022, effective September 9, 2022 (D.C. Law 24-166; 69 DCR 8870), is amended by striking the phrase "to exceed $25,000 of this amount" and inserting the phrase "to exceed $40,000 of this amount" in its place.

section.heading: Fiscal impact statement.
section.text: The Council adopts the fiscal impact statement of the Budget Director as the fiscal impact statement required by section 4a of the General Legislative Procedures Act of 1975, approved October 16, 2006 (120 Stat. 2038; D.C. Official Code ยง 1-301.47a).

section.heading: Effective date.
section.text: This act shall take effect following approval by the Mayor (or in the event of veto by the Mayor, action by the Council to override the veto), and shall remain in effect for no longer than 90 days, as provided for emergency acts of the Council of the District of Columbia in section 412(a) of the District of Columbia Home Rule Act, approved December 24, 1973 (87 Stat. 788; D.C. Official Code ยง 1-204.12(a)).
